column4: hi, can I format allocated space on the disk I am currently running ubuntu on ?
unallocated space is space  that can be used for a new partition

unused space, the first partition on the disk is the ubuntu i am currently on, then there's a second partition which is formatted and mounted, and lastly unallocated space, so i can format that without unmounting the other partitions ?
you don't format unalloacted space, because it's not being used by anything
or, i mean create a partition on it...
install gparted if it's not already installed
yes i have gparted, ...and how risky is it ? i don't want to break anything in the other 2 partitions...:p
well you can always backup first before doing anything with partitions, right?    however   if your careful and only  do stuff with the unalloacted space, you should be ok
what kind of partition do you want to make?
ok thanks, in fact that was my other question, is there a partition I can make that can be mounted by a mac OSX system ?
I think nearly anything can,  fat32 and so on
well fat32  should be able to do for sure
I don't know much about Macs when it comes to partitining as I expect most people here don't either,  you could ask in ##mac
hmm but fat32 doesn't allow to write files bigger than 3Gig...
I am not sure what file systems Mac OS X suppourts, but I expect they know in ##mac
